holidays.name: National Twilight Zone Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the groundbreaking sci-fi TV series "The Twilight Zone," created by Rod Serling, which first aired on this day in 1959. Dive into eerie tales and mind-bending twists!
holidays.origin: Marks the premiere date of the iconic TV show "The Twilight Zone."
holidays.funFact: Rod Serling often wrote episodes with social commentary cleverly disguised as science fiction.

holidays.name: Eat What You Want Day
holidays.description: A guilt-free holiday that lets you indulge in any food you desire without watching your diet or counting calories ‚Äì because you deserve it!
holidays.origin: An unofficial holiday encouraging people to satisfy their cravings and embrace self-care through food.
holidays.funFact: Some people celebrate by eating an entire pizza or their favorite dessert first thing in the morning!

holidays.name: Cassoulet Day
holidays.description: Honor the hearty French dish cassoulet, a rich, slow-cooked casserole with beans, sausages, and meats, perfect for comfort food lovers.
holidays.origin: Celebrated to showcase traditional regional dishes of France, especially in the southwest.
holidays.funFact: True cassoulet can take days to prepare ‚Äì slow cooking is key to its legendary flavor.

holidays.name: National Twilight Zone Day
holidays.description: Commemorates the debut of the classic anthology series presenting strange, mysterious, and thought-provoking stories every episode.
holidays.origin: Commemorates the very first episode aired on May 11, 1959, called "Where Is Everybody?"
holidays.funFact: The show inspired numerous remakes, movies, and even theme park attractions.
